home.title: Read Less. Understand Better.
home.subtitle: Intuition Check
home.submitDescription: Drop any URL to check your intuition. We'll generate a magic link in minutes.
home.queueBanner: You have {count} {count, plural, one {quiz} other {quizzes}} ready in your queue!

question1.prompt: You are about to tackle a dense 5,000-word essay on a new subject. According to cognitive science, which approach will help you retain the most information?
question1.option1: Attempt to guess the author's conclusions before reading a single word.
question1.option1Rationale: Correct. This triggers the "Pre-test Effect," opening a knowledge gap your brain wants to fill.
question1.option2: Read the text carefully from start to finish to ensure you don't miss context.
question1.option2Rationale: Incorrect. Passive reading often leads to brain rot and low retention.
question1.remediationBody:
Don't Read. Start Guessing.

Actually, the best way to start reading is to predict the answers first. This isn't cheating; it's priming. By guessing, you turn passive consumption into an active hunt for answers.
question1.sourceAnchor: The Science: Why "Guessing" Makes You a Better Reader

question2.prompt: True or False: The primary reason your "Read Later" list keeps growing is a lack of personal discipline.
question2.option1Rationale: Not quite. The text argues this is a structural problem, not a character flaw.
question2.option2Rationale: Correct. You aren't lazy; you just lack the right leverage for high-friction tasks.
question2.remediationBody:
It's Not Laziness. It's Friction.

Your list is a graveyard of good intentions because reading to learn requires high energy in a low-energy world. The problem isn't your work ethic; it's that you are trying to work without leverage.
